I found the digital display attractive, with its grey numbers on a soft green background. The wide snooze button is easy to tap even with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons, which felt nice to touch, distracted me when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out, which we all liked. However, we found it complicated to set up, but mastering it made us feel sophisticated.

Tom Granger criticized this model for its built-in lamp, calling it "unbelievably tacky." He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was difficult to position and not bright enough to read by, as it only lit up the clock, which was already illuminated. Paul Bridges found the lamp amusing but agreed that tuning the radio was challenging. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, making me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. Aimed at young people, its bright colors appealed to the child in both Tom Granger and me. Tom said he would choose this one because it stands out more than the others. In fact, its traditional controls were the only ones we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual states, "the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time." Paul Bridges laughed at this, calling the model "terribly fiddly" and "completely useless."

The simplest and cheapest model we tested scored points with Tom Granger because it was "very standard and took up little space," and it had old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, "It's more intuitive to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed all the buttons correctly, so you can’t be confident it will work." He acknowledged that manufacturers had to improve radio quality due to the rise of button-tuning. I found the tuning a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, with their spines pointing outward for protection. The effectiveness of this defense depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, making them more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up, using their ball-rolling ability only as a last option.

Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. While all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do; some will stay awake all year if the conditions are right.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often face even greater difficulties. Training and competing leave little time for a normal life, requiring many sacrifices. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and setting new records. Here, we highlight some remarkable British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land safely, but it can be frightening. Sometimes I don’t feel well, or the weather is bad, but I push through. Having a career outside of skiing is tough because we train for ten months each year. I have to give up a lot of my social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete on the same courses and are treated equally—it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race and surprisingly won because I cycled faster than everyone else, even though I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for endorsements. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks rather than my skills. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day, plus I do stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the commitment needed."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is difficult for girls to start because very few schools offer it. Most girls begin at 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to instability in the women's team. Despite these challenges, I enjoy it and love staying fit, plus there’s a good social aspect."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how vast it was! I found Britain too safe and restrictive. I was very determined and disliked being controlled. Each walk has been unique. The walk across Australia was the hardest experience due to the pain. I walked 50 miles a day with only three hours of sleep in extreme heat, suffering from many blisters. But I set a record! I had to, as my sponsorship money was running out after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, which is noticeable on the roads. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I approach a corner, men think they must beat me, so I’ve had my share of accidents! You need to be competitive and aggressive. It’s hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s great that more women are joining racing every year. For me, the thrill of saloon car racing is striving for perfection and aiming for the perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There’s a lot of nervousness before races, and I really push myself—if I don’t, I feel bad. I’ve often wondered why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also less for women. However, we have now established an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**Simplified Text:**

The day I met Picasso, Richard Cork remembers how, as a student at 78 years old, he encountered one of the greatest artists of the century. Even from a distance, while he was eating lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes, Picasso was easy to recognize. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old, unreliable van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have a sketchbook with me when I met the famous artist.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually worked alone in the hills. So, I was very surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would never have approached him to ask for his signature. I was nervous as I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added a lively drawing below. Even when Picasso's art was abstract, it often connected to real things. The lines he drew might represent a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor, which he could see from where he was sitting.

I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was even worse, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak freely. Still, I managed to tell Picasso about my strong interest in art and my admiration for his work. After a while, I went back to the boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But he noticed that the lunch was still going on. "Is that all?" he asked, looking at the signature. "Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this opportunity? You might not get another chance like this, and he probably wouldn’t mind if you drew his portrait."

With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was best not to ask if I could draw him, as he might say no and ruin the moment. So, I just stood by the table, set my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and began to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled mischievously and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny and strange expressions—rolling his eyes, sticking out his tongue, and making silly shapes with his hands. It was like he was a playful clown. I felt like giving up, but his playful spirit seemed to challenge me to keep going. Despite his antics, I thought he was testing my determination.

Eventually, Picasso relaxed and allowed me to study him without distractions. I noticed how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed more like a fit 60-year-old than a man about to turn 84. His dark eyes were youthful and intense, and I tried to capture that in my drawing. They were captivating, and he didn’t blink as he looked around. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed distant and alone. His playful behavior hid a serious side. He let his friends talk while he sat quietly, focused on his own thoughts.

When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketchbook, he nodded approvingly. To my surprise, he then said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick, confident strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a face that was very different from my careful attempt. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks. Maybe he saw me as someone from another world, amazed to meet an artist he admired.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. After talking with the American woman, she explained that he said I already had his signature. So, there were limits to his generosity! Still, I look back and feel grateful. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant a lot to me.

**Text: Shopping Strategies**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This text explains the techniques that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

**A. Freshness Appeal**  
Supermarkets understand that customers value fresh food. To create this impression, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance or display house plants. They might also have a bakery that fills the store with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh produce. However, most items sold in supermarkets, like frozen foods and cleaning products, do not match this fresh image.

**B. Strategic Product Placement**  
The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales, especially in supermarkets. With advanced stock management systems, supermarkets can identify which areas attract the most shoppers. They place high-profit items in these areas, while also using eye-level shelves to promote certain brands. Special bins with discounts attract bargain hunters, and complementary items, like desserts next to ice cream, encourage additional purchases.

**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This forces shoppers to walk past more expensive items, increasing the chances of impulse buys. Chain stores also position their popular products away from the entrance, hoping loyal customers will search for them and encounter other tempting items along the way.

**D. Less is More**  
In recent years, chain stores have changed how they display products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from a crowded display style to a more boutique-like approach, showcasing limited fashion items. This creates an impression of exclusivity, even though their clothing is still mass-produced. Their success is due to both effective store design and appealing clothing.

**E. Total Costs Matter**  
Food shoppers often focus more on the total cost of their shopping rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items to attract customers. They may even sell some staples at a loss to draw in shoppers, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They achieve low prices by buying in bulk and negotiating discounts with manufacturers.

**F. The Price Tag**  
Customers tend to buy fewer items in chain stores and pay more attention to individual prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can influence buying decisions. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

**G. Effective Lighting**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural daylight, helping customers see the true colors of clothing. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to highlight fresh produce.

**H. Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers through the store. These paths, known as the "Yellow Brick Road," encourage customers to explore. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use attractive flooring to lead shoppers into sales areas.

**I. In-Store Advertising**  
As you enter a supermarket, large colorful images of delicious food catch your eye, especially if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that display advertisements as you shop. These trolleys use sensors to show relevant ads, aiming to increase impulse purchases by about 30%.

**Text: Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington, aged 58, is famous for reaching the top of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail, where I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first experience on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 

When we reached a large drop, I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how to do it. After I finished, Robin politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, while I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit worried, but he managed to lower himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion that we combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural progression from our Skye adventure. 

I was very impressed by Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin always consulted the crew first. Most of the time, no one dared to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing quite challenging and boring. The moments of crisis were easier to handle because they got my adrenaline pumping. However, I struggled with spending days in the middle of the sea. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.

The crew was also cramped, with six people on a 32-foot yacht designed for four. On a mountain expedition, you can get some space from each other. When we arrived in Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times when, if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be very careful. I underestimated how difficult climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 

The first time we tried to reach the top, we were active for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges, but he completely trusted me and just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted my decision. I also knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether it could get through the ice and if it was still intact. However, he was supportive of trying to climb the mountain again.

The only time we had a serious issue was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to keep watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt that he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I expressed this to him. Robin quickly reassured me that I had misunderstood the situation. While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we truly got to know each other by the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind-hearted and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life for thousands of years, existing in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since prehistoric times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains that turned to carbon near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people even stored dried apple halves for winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and shriveled, which were known in Ancient Britain as 'windings.' They were very different from the apples we eat today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge included cider-making and was brought to Britain during Roman times. One dessert apple, called Decio, was thought to have been introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in the British climate, and Norman varieties quickly became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple varieties, which are the ancestors of most Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
During the thirteenth century, several apple types became common in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, and it gave rise to the term 'costermonger,' meaning a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This situation continued until the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern-style orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers who traveled to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them valuable possessions. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought the first apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the well-known apple planter was John Chapman, also known as 'Johnny Appleseed.' Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans viewed him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unique clothing, and religious beliefs led to many folktales about him, including one that said he was so kind to animals that he even slept with bears.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named this apple 'Hawkey.' After he presented it at a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples in the world.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous modern apple was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was the daughter of convicts but chose to live independently, rejecting her parents' criminal past and the colonial system. Working as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales, she became known as 'Granny Smith' for managing the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she found a small tree growing among discarded fruit. She transplanted it, and soon she was harvesting the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she said, "Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the apple and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown globally, from Himachal Pradesh in northern India to luxury orchards in Africa. However, most apples are commercially grown and come from only a few varieties, often chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, rather than for their taste. This trend of uniformity is dulling our taste and reducing genetic diversity. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apple types from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are beginning to demand more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity or any other food. We must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups Leave Few Footprints**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique and interesting destinations with original itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last between 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups are small, averaging 16 people, and are led by experienced guides. This allows you to truly discover the places we visit. Being part of a small group means you can connect more with the local culture and people, making for a rewarding experience.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various forms of transport during our trips, often combining several on the same journey. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, light plane, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the character of the local environment.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting individuals who are ready to embrace new experiences. Most come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are designed for anyone in good health who is reasonably fit and adaptable. Most participants are between 25 and 55 years old, with about half being couples and the rest solo travelers.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip with Explore Worldwide is unique, so we categorize our adventures into eight different themes, highlighting key activities and interests. Each category showcases special features of a tour, but many other elements contribute to the overall success of the trips, such as unique locations, cultural encounters, and personal experiences.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most of our trips have a strong cultural aspect, with some focusing primarily on local cultures and historical sites. Destinations of cultural interest include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Many trips include short walks to visit lesser-known sites.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, allowing thrilling encounters with animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might have the chance to explore the wild on foot, tracking animals like the rare silver-back mountain gorilla or going on bush walks with local guides. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel accommodations.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg of the Sahara or the Maya of Mexico. Many of these groups have traditional lifestyles that are under threat. We travel in small groups to promote understanding and respect for different cultures while minimizing our impact on their environments.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walking through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented accommodations or hotels. Some involve village-to-village hiking, where you may stay overnight in local homes or simple huts. Destinations for these hikes include Spain, Greece, Morocco, and Thailand. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a small daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer a few challenging treks for experienced hikers, sometimes at high altitudes. These trips may involve staying with local people or camping in stunning mountain ranges like the Himalayas or the Andes. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided, so you won’t need to carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. These places, like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert, offer unique experiences for adventurous travelers.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays involve traveling by local boats, such as feluccas in Egypt or gulets in Turkey. We also explore the Galapagos Islands on a small motor yacht.

**Raft and River Journeys**

Our river journeys can last from a few hours to several days, ranging from easy inflatable rafts to thrilling whitewater rafting. No prior experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon provide a unique view of the local landscapes and wildlife.

Text: Richard Nerurkar, a top 10,000-metre runner from Britain, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a sunny mountain track leads from a quiet road in Nairobi. This track begins the journey up Mount Kenya, the country’s highest peak. For the past three years, I have used Nanyuk as my base for winter altitude training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners before. On my fourth winter training trip to Kenya, I decided to change that. I participated in my first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I received this opportunity after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. Training at high altitude increases the number of red blood cells, which helps improve oxygen delivery in the body. This has contributed to the success of many Kenyan runners.

My first race in Africa was also significant because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent, taking place in Nairobi. It was a humbling experience, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, with only three not being Kenyan. Despite this, I felt I had performed well. However, I believe that Kenyan success is not solely due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a straightforward approach to the sport. Their running style appears effortless, their diet is simple, and they enjoy competing. One important aspect of their success is their training methods, which I learned about during my time at the training camp.

The national team camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mt Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. The facilities are basic, with athletes living among regular students in shared dormitories. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. The day starts at six in the morning, with a briefing from the coaches. We were reminded to take it easy during the morning run, as a harder workout was planned for later. Each day, we covered about 40 kilometers, except on Sundays when we only ran 20 kilometers, which was a welcome break.

Life at the camp was simple. A splash of water on the face and brushing teeth were enough for morning preparations. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, featuring ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to bathe in streams fed by Mt Kenya's glaciers. By the end of my stay, I gained a deeper appreciation for Kenyan success. It cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simplicity of life in the mountains, the intense training, and the passion for success might be the true reasons behind Kenya's dominance in distance running.

**Text: The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

As many people know, advertising is struggling. This issue is not only due to the recession; advertising began to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are deeper and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about mass markets and mass media, but as brands and media have increased, target markets have become more divided. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not.

Consider your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen a year, and for cars, you may only buy one every three years. Even when you include all types of products and services, it is likely that you do not purchase more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In contrast, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we focus on the 9,500 brands that are individually listed and analyzed, the average person only buys about 400 of these brands, which is only about 4 percent. This challenges the common belief that half of advertising is wasted, as it suggests that 96 percent of advertising may not lead to purchases, but we cannot know which part is wasted.

When you watch TV, try to count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. Most people find that only about 6 percent of the commercials are relevant to them, meaning that 94 percent may be wasted. Many people believe they are not influenced by advertising, but the reality is that most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised. 

Waste is a natural part of advertising. The idea that every person who sees an advertisement will rush to buy the product is unrealistic. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many advertisements have shown that it can work. Advertisers need to reach a large audience to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as they cannot predict who will be interested in their products.

Even with careful targeting, advertisers cannot know exactly who will respond to their ads. For example, even the best direct mail campaigns do not achieve a 100 percent response rate. This is a key difference between media advertising and personal selling. A salesperson might succeed with every potential client they meet, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would communicate with them directly instead of using mass media.

Any advertiser who can attract one million new customers, which is about 2 percent of the adult population, is considered successful. For popular products, gaining a million extra customers would be a great achievement. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can reach 2 percent of the population would be seen as very successful, even though this is a small part of the total population. While mass media can be an effective way to reach people, if advertising is to improve, it must focus more on specific audiences than ever before.

**Simplified Text:**

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits Britain's Greenest Home**

Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting features. First, it is home to Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral. Writers who care about the environment admire the 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen in the cathedral's thirteenth-century chapter house. 

The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. This house is designed to be very eco-friendly. The Vales collect rainwater for drinking and washing, recycle their sewage into compost for their garden, and use waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat to warm the house. This includes heat from their three teenage children and their two cats, Edison and Faraday. 

The house looks traditional, with a roof made of clay tiles, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the orange brick of the town's nineteenth-century buildings and received approval from planners, even though it is in a conservation area. When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice complete silence. The house is very well insulated, with special triple-glazed windows that keep out noise. 

Inside, after taking off your shoes (as Robert requests), you will find a peaceful atmosphere. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow, as the house is designed to be draught-proof. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide. They then decided to eliminate the need for mains water as well. They designed composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.

Robert explains, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment without living in darkness. It does not have to be medieval." The only medieval feature is the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, stretching the full height of the house. 

The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating. Soon, they will install solar water heating panels and equipment in the garden, which will allow the house to generate more electricity than it needs. One day, they hope to have enough electricity to charge an electric car.

The only source of heat in the house is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which the Vales say they only use during the coldest winter days. When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but he found it comfortable because there were no draughts and everything felt warm to the touch. 

Robert points out that a woman living in the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. He suggests that people living in older homes should adapt to how people lived back then, but this idea may not be popular. 

The secret to the house's success is its simple design, which means there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were bought from a local builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen, making the house affordable to build. It cost the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are not keen on this idea.

Text: 'The Camera Never Lies

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, considered himself a rational person and even a scientist. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article where he accepted fairies as supernatural beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are undeniably beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick challenges a basic idea of photography: that the camera cannot lie. In reality, it can, and it always has. Today, we often use computer software to edit our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the beginning, when cameras started capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

**Text: Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths held a status similar to that of doctors and astrologers because they were the only ones who made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St. Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture was crafted by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used the graceful wrought iron designs. In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more open-minded approach to interior design. Still, much of the work produced seems clichéd, with manufacturers of gates and balconies promoting their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can hardly enter a trendy design store without seeing rusty candlesticks with unnecessary decorations.

Fortunately, there are alternatives, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmithing craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, states, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently." Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld with less effort. Dawson adds, "These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves."

About 250 pieces have been created for the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork. Dawson's contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a mouth-blown glass shade. He explains, "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space."

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, describes it as "magical" because it is very soft when hot but becomes hard and unyielding when it cools. Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, while another resembles a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever."

No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for the next thousand years, as long as we can avoid seeing any more rusty candlesticks.

**Text: 'THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING'**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying, even for me. The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I hadn’t planned to quit, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop; it wouldn’t be fair." I was there to write, not to quit, so I thought it wouldn’t be right to expect the method to work for me. I enjoyed smoking; it gave me real pleasure. The counsellor seemed to understand this. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. 

What happened was that the messages about stopping made sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of quitting started to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that didn’t involve anyone else. Could I also achieve other things? In many ways, it was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, faded after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it turned out to be fine. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing simple things at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 

I am starting to think that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—like eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

**Simplified Text:**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know about her. If they respond positively, they pass my test. Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? The fact that she won a Nobel Prize should be enough. If someone in literature had the same achievement, they would be famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person, as complex as the crystals she studied. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the global nature of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend and worked in the same field. I went to a local bookstore but found no biographies of Pauling. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a major chemist and won Nobel Prizes for both chemistry and peace. Even scientists sometimes think that biographies of scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, a Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers think the same way.

Scientists are often treated differently from other people in biographies, which reflects the idea that there is a big gap between the arts and sciences. Only a few famous scientists have biographies in bookstores. It is not true that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. One geneticist told me he would not want to be quoted or photographed because he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This avoidance of personal stories can give a wrong impression of science and may discourage young people from pursuing it.

Fortunately, things are changing. Nowadays, scientists often appear in public in ways other than just scientific interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives out prizes on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help people see scientists as real individuals, more than just their academic work.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and dull, often ignoring the personal lives of scientists. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been shown with their flaws. Readers find it interesting to see how creative geniuses deal with personal challenges, even if those challenges seem unrelated to their scientific work.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her science. She made significant discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and insulin, which her team solved in 1969. She achieved these successes by pushing scientific techniques to new levels. However, she also raised three children and was married to a husband who was often away due to his job as a historian. While her personal life may not seem directly related to her science, it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.

There is much in her life that is interesting to everyone, but her scientific work is also important. Scientific research was her passion, which is essential for any successful scientist. The challenge for biographers is to communicate this passion. Many readers may not have enough scientific knowledge to understand complex ideas without detailed explanations. Understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that educated people, who would feel embarrassed if they did not know a famous writer or artist, often do not recognize the valuable contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Text: Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Farmers whose wells have dried up are increasingly seeking her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern technology like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, when it comes to finding water, she relies only on her forked hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground is known as dowsing. There are many theories about how dowsing works, ranging from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual ideas. One of the most believable theories suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers believe they can sense these vibrations, while others claim they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to drought, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns that have become holiday homes, where running water pipes over long distances is too expensive. There are also golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret typically looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She emphasizes that it is important not to drill where there is a risk of contamination from waste. The water she finds is usually in cracks in solid rock, and if they bring it up properly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, there are many minerals, so they must be careful about iron in the water. 

Another important factor is electricity to power the pump, which can be costly to run over long distances. Therefore, it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. Once she considers all these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. 

For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. It will swing when she is above a water source. After identifying possible locations on the map, she walks over the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. 

"When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. Once that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret's husband also dowse the same area. Usually, but not always, they agree on the exact drilling spot. If they disagree, they will not drill until they reach a consensus.

Margaret Wilkins is not alone in her practice; many anthropologists and writers have been intrigued by this mysterious ability. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard to understand how her family could continue to thrive in their well-drilling business year after year.

**Simplified Text: 'We Changed Lives for a Day!'**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be fun to try something completely different. We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**A. Amanda's Story**

I had never been in a place like this before. It was dark and noisy, with many people and a lively atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and honestly, I wasn't sure I could handle it! Being a mother is a busy job, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks started to slide off the tray and fell to the floor, spilling cocktails everywhere. I felt so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!

By opening time at 11:30 am, there was already a line outside, and I started to feel really nervous. I worried about remembering all the orders, but luckily, everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn’t get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say 'Pardon?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was completely exhausted and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn’t believe it when one of the waitresses said it had been a 'quiet' day! I never realized how tiring waitressing could be. I always thought it was an easy job, but you really need to be friendly and able to handle a lot of customers at once. I’m quite shy, and I don’t think I could manage on a busy Saturday night. I wasn’t impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers didn’t tip me! I was very happy to return to my children. It felt easy compared to waitressing!

**B. Cindy's Story**

I was nervous about being a 'mum' for a day, but I was also excited. I had been told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could manage. As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of peace. I was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, rushed through the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble began. They turned the couch into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming as loudly as they could! I thought they would tire out soon, but I was wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they outlasted me! After much persuasion, I finally got them to bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun began! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I realized they were just trying to come downstairs to watch television, but it was exhausting to negotiate with them all evening. I never knew how tiring it could be to take care of two small children. You don’t have a moment to think about yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Still, I really enjoyed the day.

**C. Rosemary's Story**

On the farm, I wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was a treat! But I took a long time deciding how to dress. I couldn’t show up in my farm clothes, could I? When I faced about 400 students at assembly, I hoped I blended in and didn’t look too much like a farmer. After that, I helped with a maths class where the children worked in small groups, which was very different from my school days when we had to recite together! Then I helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding different types of snails.

By lunchtime, I was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There’s so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and ended up helping with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (which was nice!) and then a French lesson in the video room. The children wanted to practice their French with me, which showed how rusty I was! Finally, we moved to the gym for Physical Education. I was exhausted, but the children had endless energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Teachers may have more holidays, but I think I’ll stick to farming!

**D. Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary’s farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, which are sold in shops and restaurants. I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, bottling milk and making ice cream. It was hard not to taste everything!

At lunchtime, I checked on the sheep. I drove to one of the fields and helped a sheep that had fallen over. If they are left for more than 12 hours, they could die, so they need to be checked daily. What a nightmare it must be in winter! After feeding the calves, I started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, every day of the year! I found it quite lonely. I missed the children a lot - animals don’t talk back! The worst part of the job is that you can’t take time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, so it’s hard to plan any time away. Rosemary will only get about three days off this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is unstable, and I wouldn’t want to depend on the weather.

**Simplified Text:**

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas. It is surprising how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces. When you meet him, he looks younger than his age, with a bright and friendly manner that matches the sound of the trumpet.

Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London’s top concert halls. A television feature was made about his work and development, filmed in both London and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give his son a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother arranged for him to take lessons from the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who recognized his natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, someone who was passionate about the trumpet and always looking for ways to improve.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to create a perfect one. There will always be some imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and build a relationship with them. From the start, he had a unique sound that was recognizable even in his childhood. Unlike John Wallace, a famous British trumpet player who came from a brass band background, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player.

At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson wanted him to go to America, it was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud confirmed Hardenberger's belief that playing in an orchestra was not for him, comparing it to digging in the garden. He knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after his first competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with people through music. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but advanced to the second. He was lucky to know most of the pieces in that round, but in the final, he faced a concerto that intimidated him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even though he felt he played poorly, people were still listening.

Hardenberger's honesty about his work might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing his gift of communication, saying, "You risk destroying it by trying to explain. The power of music lies in its ability to move people."

**Text:**

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insight. It is a challenging but rewarding read.

**B.** Harriet is a composed, middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe, although physically recovering, becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

**C.** This book, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After his recent success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies, accompanied by her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her enjoyable manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary aspects of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright moments.

**E.** Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time adrift on "the desert cities of waves." The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who share their different jobs, discussing the positives, negatives, and their typical workdays.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7:00 am, and arrive at work by 8:00 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries last about three hours, but some can take all day. Occasionally, I work for ten hours straight without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about the next day’s operations. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it is incredibly rewarding, making up for the times it doesn’t. From 10:00 am to 1:00 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain the surgeries to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time pressure can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call and carry my bleeper. During holidays, I often worry about my patients and dream about operating at night. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. I work in a team of three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My work is mostly production, with about ten to fifteen percent being design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, and deadlines are always tight. I usually have lunch at 1:00 pm for an hour, often going to the pub, but sometimes I eat sandwiches while working. It feels great when a client appreciates my designs, but it’s disappointing when a project I worked hard on gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be much later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7:00 am, but on two or three mornings a week, I wake up between 4:30 am and 5:00 am to meet long-haul flights. At 10:30 or 11:00 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sedentary job, I need to watch my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. People often ask for my recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, allowing me to plan my routes. While most passengers are polite, some can be rude. I have built good relationships with my regular clients. Sometimes, I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7:00 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11:00 am, we take a break at a local café for a big breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10:00 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants their garden landscaped, I usually schedule a consultation in the evening. We focus on using old materials to create gardens that look historic. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren’t great, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we designed bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone ringing. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, leaving me exhausted at the end of the day. I may not be very strong, but I am fit. It’s a tough job, but it allows for creativity."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that contractors are following the schedule and safety guidelines while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site professionals and solve any problems. The contractors start work at 6:00 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day is based on what I learn from the clerk of works. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. I take a half-hour lunch break between 2:00 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we monitor the contractors' work, it can lead to conflicts, so we need to maintain an open relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but I act quickly if something urgent arises. I typically leave the site around 6:00 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and reach the office by 7:30 am. My job involves managing customer development programs for our credit card users. I am responsible for launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I need to maintain contact with current card users, attract new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I oversee advertising for the membership program across Europe, which requires meetings with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to address any issues. When I am in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and start by reviewing the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for specific artists. I listen to demo tapes carefully, knowing that they represent people's hard work, and I try to provide constructive feedback. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, selecting songs, producers, and additional musicians. I also communicate my vision for the album to the marketing team. I manage budgets and expenses as well. I typically leave work by 7:00 pm, and most evenings I attend concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new bands in one night. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I start by opening the mail and checking the schedule for client meetings. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and love the satisfaction of making a sale. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, sourcing them from auctions, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work closely with our full-time restorer and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while enjoying coffee to stay updated on the industry, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle the accounts once a month and complete tax returns every three months. I leave work at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over one of the control positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, working for about an hour and a half at one station, then taking a half-hour break before switching to another station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle around 1,000 movements daily, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read about new air traffic regulations between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. This job can be stressful, and I prioritize my health, taking sick days if I feel unwell. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. My first task is to set up the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is watching the till and coordinate staff lunches and breaks. In the morning, I assist customers in finding and ordering books. I enjoy helping customers, although it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers' representatives visit, and I discuss upcoming titles with them. I need to estimate how many copies of a new title we might sell. When we want to feature a new title, I ensure it arrives on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work a late shift, during which I close the computer system, lock up, and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. My first task is to contact freelance reporters to learn about developments in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, aiming to warn clients about potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second by 11:00 am, so I need to work quickly. I write the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and make any necessary changes. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events and stay updated. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, and it can be hard to relax in the evenings; I often find myself awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and drives change. Leadership is not about physical traits like height, nor is it just about intelligence. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is essential, and a good leader should communicate clearly and confidently. Dixon emphasizes the importance of saying "I believe" instead of "I think."

**B. Potential for Leadership**  
John van Maurik, director of a Leadership in Management course, states that most people have more potential for leadership than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it is easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

**C. Comparing Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? A good leader motivates and supports you, while a bad leader makes you feel unimportant and blames you when things go wrong. The first person led well; the second just managed poorly.

**D. Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers prefer to work within set limits, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, writes that a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.

**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to consider:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Discover your passions and act on them when you feel inspired.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is good, but sometimes strong leadership is necessary. Try different leadership styles. If you usually negotiate, take the lead instead and see how it changes the outcome.  
- Set goals and strive to exceed them. Identify areas in your job where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career opportunities.

**F. Developing Leadership**  
Leadership does not happen by itself. It develops through taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and provide feedback.  
- Don’t assume your leadership style will be immediately accepted by your colleagues; it might even push them away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to those who matter. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Understand when your contribution is crucial and how you can help others become leaders.

**Text: Films on Video - Film Critic Nick James Reviews Recent Releases**

A. **Abyss**  
Before *Titanic*, director James Cameron created this intense Cold War thriller about oil workers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The friendly banter and modest bravery of foreman Bud and his team remind us of similar heroes in films by Howard Hawks. The production design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and character development feel weak. Despite the skill in filmmaking, the story is basic B-movie material.

B. **The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, offers a different perspective compared to Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's film is more traditional, focusing on a single soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially the flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife, which is portrayed more harshly than Malick's softer imagery.

C. **On Guard**  
Loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, this entertaining swashbuckler is better than most musketeer films. It features a skilled villain, played by Fabrice Luchini, who causes chaos behind the scenes. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short-lived.
