Raquel did not apply for this job; she met the manager of a pop group by chance, which led to her behind-the-scenes work. She also took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. He prefers caddying because golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, with average earnings between £25,000 and £35,000, much of which goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You're not just carrying bags; you're giving advice, using your knowledge, and reading the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, which made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are valuable to TV commentators, golf magazines, and the players.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the "Food and Drink" section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to taste food at fine restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in my guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed writing, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. Having been a farmer, I knew about the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called *The Fox Busters*, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work for them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don't wake up at dawn, though. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning—all with one finger on an old typewriter instead of a laptop, which I dislike. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but I now have some secretarial help."

Text: In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Surrounding it were large piles of soft sawdust, creating golden mounds that reached down to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, a group of boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down." Without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too. 

Still laughing, he watched as they hesitated on the roof, looking scared. One by one, they jumped down, relieved to land safely. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes. Eventually, one of the boys suggested, "Let's go back up to the roof and jump down again." Although they were not very excited, they climbed back up and began jumping off in a determined way. Soon, only Michael was left on the roof, while the others grinned up at him, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?" 

Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed at the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning foolishly. He wondered why the jump had not seemed so scary the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they noticed him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and jump, but when that didn't work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. 

After a while, the boys started laughing at him. They were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn't move, they began to walk away, still teasing him. "Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called out. But he remained on the edge of the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. 

He stayed there alone for nearly an hour while the sun slowly set over the lake. His clothes were damp from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. 

He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time. If you won't come home, you might as well stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a hint of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. Although she spoke firmly, Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her. He was still thinking about the grinning faces below and their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change their careers turn to a careers adviser. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. Afterward, you will receive a summary of the results, along with suggested careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest career advice organizations. Taking the careers test felt like being back in a science exam. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I had to remind myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was difficult to see how the psychometric tests could accurately represent me. The tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, although I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m sure many sick people are relieved I never became a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean a complete shift. Last March, after working as a marketing manager at a large insurance company for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends encouraged her to seek help from Career Analysts. "Losing my job was a great chance for me to step back and evaluate my career," Donna says. "I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had such a talent for design. But in the end, I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial responsibilities," she explains. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. "I chose to use my existing skills and move into a field that suited me better than insurance. I am now a Public Relations officer. I believe I would have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me understand what I truly wanted to do. I’ve recommended them to several friends, and they are all satisfied with the service."

Not everyone finds career advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says, "I reached a point in my career where I felt lost. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either required a significant pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself," she says. "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Text: Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental clinic in the center of Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he examines their teeth. Jerome mentions, "Fifty percent of people only visit the dentist when they are in pain instead of going for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has worked to create a space where people feel comfortable. For example, he decided not to wear a white coat, as many people link it to pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This approach may surprise many, as most people associate dental visits with discomfort or formal settings. Jerome states, "If patients are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his innovative relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the initial check-up, the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then, the headset switches to a special camera that gives the patient a visual tour of their mouth."

Interestingly, most patients seem to enjoy this part of their dental visit. Another important aspect is that the clinic smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, there is a pleasant smell of orange. Jerome explains, "When people enter, I want them to realize through all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is crucial. The usual dental smell can make someone anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the clinic very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. While relaxation techniques are important, the quality of treatment is the top priority. For instance, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping, which can feel strange at first, but is not painful if the patient is relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned is that making it easier for the patient also makes it easier for the dentist," he explains. He believes his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a shift towards a more relaxed style in the traditional British dentistry field.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently guides him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this luxurious treatment, and it is easy to see why. The clinic feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Text: Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which originated in South America, is now a major global business worth millions. During Easter, British people spend over £230 million on chocolate, with eight percent of all chocolate sales happening at this time. Only at Christmas do people consume more chocolate. 

Although large-scale chocolate production started in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often mistakenly called cocoa beans, a misspelling from the 17th century when they were also referred to as cacoa and cocao beans. 

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as currency and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in the Aztec language, Nahuatl. In Aztec times, this chocolate drink was flavored with spices and served during ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish found it more enjoyable when mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but the recipe did not reach the rest of Europe for another hundred years. 

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when a Bristol company, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid block. A Swiss company later added milk solids, resulting in milk chocolate.

At the turn of the century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. Then, Cadbury introduced the Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it to the health benefits of milk from the English countryside, making it a strong competitor to luxurious French brands. 

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars per week, prompting manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One recent marketing strategy is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are transformed into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something new. 

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, consider the challenges faced by these farmers.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master in his craft. He still has many interests, such as paper-making and feather-work, but for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells. As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Tell me if I am boring you." There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is clearly the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I’ve grown so fond of them. I never intended to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends suggested I have an exhibition so people could see my art. They even spoke to a gallery owner." This led to a successful exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. Given the high prices of his work—around £2,000 for the ornaments—Cooke seems to think that giving up some space above his fireplace is a small price to pay.

There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke insists he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes that no one else creates work like his, and as the gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won’t be any more."

Cooke wishes he had started this art earlier in life, as he feels he could have created even more wonderful things. Although he still has many ideas and does his best now, he feels more limited physically than when he began. Nevertheless, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led him to create boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own methods and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he explains about his working process. However, the attention to detail, color variations, and symmetry in his work seem far from random.

Cooke's search for beautiful, especially tiny, shells has taken him beyond his local beaches in Norfolk to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of damaging the environment. "When I collect shells, I hear people stepping on them much faster than I can gather them. The remaining shells are broken by the sea. I would never collect shells with living creatures inside or dive for them, but once the creatures have left, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially considering the beauty of his work often exceeds the sum of its parts.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who balances her modeling career with school. When she is not traveling to exciting places or appearing on magazine covers, she is studying for her exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about her.

The receptionist at Kira's modeling agency informed me that Kira would be late. I thought about the negative stereotypes I had heard about models, such as being difficult or vain. I worried that Kira might not show up at all or that she would be in a bad mood if she rushed in. However, when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, calm, and accompanied by her mother. She wore a simple black dress and trainers, showing no signs of arrogance. Instead, she was friendly and approachable.

Kira explained that models under 16 must bring an adult with them to work. Her mother, who looked proud of her daughter, was just a regular mom. Kira seemed a bit surprised by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. Kira initially said no, but her sister submitted some photos anyway. When Kira learned she was a finalist while at school, she gained the confidence to participate, and she won easily. The Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Now, Kira finds it challenging to manage her two lives as a student and a model. Her friends and teachers are proud of her success, but some classmates make rude comments, saying she has a high opinion of herself. Kira finds this difficult, especially since she is not self-important. She explains, "They think that because I became a model, I can't stay the same. The only change is that I am more confident, but not in a bad way."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job the next day, making it hard for her to make plans with friends. "If my friends go out, I can't promise to join them because I don't know my schedule," she says. However, her friends understand and do not complain about her modeling commitments.

Kira has the talent, looks, and support to have a successful career ahead of her, even before finishing her school exams. As I conclude the interview with this remarkable girl, I ask what she would like to do if she didn't have her beauty. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

**Simplified Text:**

Father and son start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the hot lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they are sure they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool.

The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to explore. Since they first cleared the land and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They have dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running low on money. After spending their savings on this dream, they need to convince someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, but we have several people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys last week, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. "If they are right, it would bring more visitors here," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if they find gold, I hope millions of people don’t come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of finding hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, where they cannot stand up or move freely, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. Rachel says, "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a very pleasant journey."

Rachel recalls her first experience in the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys releasing black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effects of a multinational program that would create a hole 150 metres through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers,' another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke, pouring out at a rate of one metre per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

Rachel shares a frightening experience from her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment on a 50-metre rope when there was an explosion. She felt a huge bang as shock waves hit their vehicle and thought, "I'm going to die." They looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to find they were still alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before." After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

Text: "I felt dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with foreign train schedules, currencies, and languages. 'Never again,' I thought as I returned home. I repeated this thought the next year and the year after that. All I needed was one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 

Once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds feel different. Carrying all your belongings in a rucksack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away finished books. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be set aside along with your paperback and socks. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. 

A system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize the full potential of this train ticket; we thought it was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of continuous travel was too appealing, as there was always another country just beyond the border, always a little further to explore. And the extra miles? They cost us nothing. 

We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. In planning our own schedule, we focused only on the most accessible sights. It was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to get by and enjoy ourselves, just like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, money, and music. 

The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of a place that was once just a name. It feels like the city you arrive in didn’t exist until the train pulls into the station, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by experiencing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means little until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be dull. While the train journey may not reveal new discoveries in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail offers the best chance to appreciate this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away."

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your bags. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck in unsuitable clothing. Although airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, it is a reality that regular travelers will eventually experience lost luggage. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and no airline can guarantee that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight, especially if your journey involves changing planes.

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which is meant to give enough time for bags to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to transfer between two flights, and these times are also extended to allow for baggage transfers. Normally, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which can disrupt the baggage system. Human error or accidents, such as a destination label being torn off, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. 

For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom transferred between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The risk of losing luggage when changing planes is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when transatlantic passengers make quick connections to Latin America.

To reduce the chance of losing your luggage, choose direct flights whenever possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all legs of your journey. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**Text: The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, creating a peaceful atmosphere, much like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, leaving a strong impression even after it disappears in an instant. 

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep affection for this small bird is shown by his uncertainty about what exactly attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess that transformed into a bird. Another story tells how the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this tale. Despite the various shades of blue in their feathers, kingfishers do not have blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers. Their vibrant colors, combined with the fact that they are shy but can be observed from a distance, create a perfect opportunity for photographers. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he draped over himself while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him another four years to capture his first good photograph. During this time, the European kingfisher became a major part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream rich with kingfishers, but school limited his time with the birds. He missed classes and considered himself an "academic failure." Nevertheless, his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was recognized. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, then became an assistant to the editor, and eventually worked as a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the ultimate kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I’m drawn to simplicity. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever reveal.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis speaks with five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna and ended up filling in for an absent assistant. She was later invited to help with another opera the following season. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous. I have always felt confident standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since that first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several projects.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after two unsuccessful attempts. Looking back, he feels lucky about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition opened many doors for him, including a position as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he struggles with being labeled as a competition winner: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired me after the competition, are inviting me back. If that doesn't happen, my career could suffer."

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size—previously, I had only learned from much larger conductors, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many conflicts, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says, "Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me." This career path is not so unusual for him; he began as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with talented conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I did my best to achieve the performance I envisioned. Thankfully, people respect my skills as a musician. I am learning from every experience I've had, both in musical style and performance. Now, I am open to any opportunities to discover what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed a young assistant conductor during one of his productions and informed his agent about Wayne Marshall. Now 32, Marshall quickly found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians who were reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best results. Many orchestral musicians I’ve encountered don’t seem to need guidance from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express my needs. If people see you’re anxious, it only gets worse. I have never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how to do it, but people have been supportive. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are considering taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids enjoyed the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young children, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, my husband Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere, and the scenery was not very appealing. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were unsure what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings that he could explore! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the areas where we could relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we felt there was still more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is also great fun for younger children. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they realized they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not boring. It was very clean, and the staff were excellent. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member kindly offered to accompany one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a fantastic theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am quite timid, but I still had a great time. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t try the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it less exciting, but they were the right age and enjoyed it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we certainly felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, stands out in the park, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were going home early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Since she had experience with computers, her husband encouraged her to start this business. Although it required a lot of money and was challenging at first, she managed her finances carefully and kept the bank informed about her spending. Working from home saves her money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, and most customers pick up their orders directly.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum. However, after moving to the countryside, she decided to start her own business, creating a collection of 50 cards that she sells to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. One downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. Maggy relies on word-of-mouth for business and does not advertise. She finds that her prices are lower than those of other artists, which attracts customers from London. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she believes the benefits of working alone outweigh the drawbacks.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when the market was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. At one point, she managed six full-time employees, but due to an economic downturn, she had to let them go, which was difficult because jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and collaborates with women who work from their homes. Delia knows she must be flexible with her prices and explore new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** operates a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the rural lifestyle. Tessa enjoys the freedom to work on her schedule, but 80% of her income comes from international deals, requiring her to take calls at unusual hours. She finds it challenging to maintain discipline and close her office door. Tessa publishes children's books that reflect various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt isolated since all her professional experience was in London.

E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that generates £250,000 a year, employing six people, some part-time. She started her business ten years ago from home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. After receiving requests from friends and family, she began shipping cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is produced, employing a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg no longer bakes herself, as she manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as she started with limited funds.

**Text: Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their father makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but found it too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years. 

After trying to make violins and violas, John successfully made his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers using that cello until recently. John has since retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. One of his violins was sold to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo, which he considers a great achievement.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano and then moved to the cello. Although their father wanted Paul to play the violin, Paul preferred the cello after being inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, now 22, is also making a name for himself as a pianist and composer. He appreciated the support from his parents and felt motivated by Paul’s success.

Paul has achieved great things with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. Recently, he has started using a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul jokes that his father's cello will improve with age, just like his new one, which is already 304 years old.

Soon, Paul will perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. He believes that his performance will be unique, regardless of the cello's history. However, he will miss watching himself on TV because he is performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, one of the wardens who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills because they interact with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies regularly. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the position of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. He says, "It helps that I still farm with my parents, so I can relate to farmers and understand their issues. They can't fool me!"

His farming background also prepares him for the physical demands of the job, such as building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers, "When I was younger, I used to pick flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and find old birds' nests. Recently, I wondered where I could find those flowers and nests now. It has become clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault; they were just following government advice."

Gareth notes that when he started, farmers and conservationists were often in conflict, each wanting things done their way. Now, they are communicating and understanding each other's perspectives. "We're at a turning point, and it only takes a small step to bring them together," he says.

Conservation is a key part of Gareth's job, along with allowing public access to the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My role is to ensure tasks are completed efficiently and with minimal fuss. I enjoy seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork."

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially interacting with the public. However, he admits, "I dislike the attitude of some visitors. They come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it. Being polite to those people can be frustrating!" But as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense. If you have plenty of that and enjoy outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just don't expect a position to open up in the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra explained, "My life right now is all about being at my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to get fit." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always won against them, but they will be exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra noted that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because you only get one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don’t train hard just to lose," Kendra said. "But once the game is over, we become friends again."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It’s essential for us to think and train like world-class players," Kendra stated. "As captain, I believe it’s important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra mentioned, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned. I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she is likely to have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their abilities. Some parents may not recognize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is seen as less important.

Children who are musically talented, along with those encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established relatively recently. These schools aim to create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, allowing them to fully develop their skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend about one third to one half of their day on music-related activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), participation in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The remainder of their time is spent on a limited academic curriculum, focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with small class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which means they spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some disadvantages. One major issue is the cost; fees for boarding students range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. Each school tries to help parents of exceptionally gifted children through scholarships and financial aid. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

It is important to note that separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, all specialist schools monitor their students closely and provide support when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some have concerns about the limited academic curriculum, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically gifted young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before pursuing a specialist education. Children who are also academically gifted may thrive in a less specialized setting, such as a school with a strong music program, or by combining a regular school schedule with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings, and the large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west show a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than painting the entire garden. However, she sometimes paints groups of plants in their natural setting. More often, she picks the flowers and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of the flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they each change into different shapes. They open up and look amazing. When you first put them in a vase, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in some shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliff tops."

Today, her garden includes many plants from distant lands, but they thrive just as well in her garden as they do in China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her subjects, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never finished, as Sarah Sutherland-Pilch explains to Veronica Lee. This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. Known as Pilch, Sarah works in Val d'Isère, France, where she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl not as a career, but as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can accommodate up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. "They get the works - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she admits is "the worst part of the job." By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can be up there until 4:30 p.m."

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower first, but she does not sleep. "It's fatal if you do," she says. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks don’t go quite so well."

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening," she says. However, she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. "A frightful day," she says, "when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted." 

On Sundays, work starts earlier than usual, as breakfast for guests must be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready." If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. "They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions. I think the mountain air affects them."

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps any guests who need boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and then getting a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner duty again, and she may chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night," she says.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my outfit for Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around when I could be quietly spending time with an animal. Some members of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job is not very pressuring. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I found it funny to think that I would usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I am interested in how magazines operate, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I petted one of the elephants, I thought Mandie was probably organizing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I was dirty but had a fantastic day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. I enjoyed being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was a lot of fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the rest of the team. My idea of gardening did not include hard physical work or careful planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would feel faint during some tasks, but I surprised myself by managing well. The friendship among the nurses is wonderful, and it felt very friendly compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less meaningful compared to nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone looked at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past stunning seascapes. No matter the weather or the time of year, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the most beautiful gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking views.

**B. Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt instead. When I moved to England as a teenager, I had never been on a train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**C. Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On that train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was wonderful. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey itself was lovely, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding preparations.

**D. Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unpredictable; we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, even climbing onto the roof for free. During the night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**E. Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains when they are young, but that’s not my case. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming took place on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had carefully maintained. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

**Text:**

Are you trying to get published? If you want to know where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" One of the first things they need to do is research their markets and learn about publishers while also improving their writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world. 

No matter what type of writing you do, it is important to know the markets you are targeting. There are several ways to do this, but the best way is to read as much relevant material as you can. Visit your local library and check out local bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

As time goes on, you need to keep this knowledge updated because new publications are always appearing—editors change jobs, and magazines change their focus. Publishers are always looking for new talent, so as writers, we must provide what they want. 

At first, you might not be sure what you want to write. For example, if you think you would like to write short love stories, the first step is to find out which magazines publish love stories, as this market is quite limited these days. Get as many recent copies of these magazines as you can and learn about the types of stories they are buying, paying attention to their readers' expectations. The editor wants to meet the needs of these readers.

Writers often ask me, "This has been rejected three times—am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. However, it is likely that the work is not yet ready for publication, so I try to give honest feedback while remaining positive. The issue is that many new writers are too eager to submit their work before they are truly ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This almost never happens. When you hear about someone's success, they usually have been in the publishing or journalism field for several years before achieving it.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, start writing more while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will improve your skills, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your confidence. Instead of giving up on your stories, work on improving them. I also recommend not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before finding success.

Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby, or consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

**Text:**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I had expected. The usual clean and bright atmosphere of the station felt lost. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags scattered on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers one by one. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn’t mind talking to her. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She replied, "Well, I’m going north, but to Philadelphia?" "No, to New York, but I’ll be..." "Thanks anyway," he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. 

"Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said, "Wilmington," he just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and drifted closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was focused on the train. I was going to Philadelphia. I understood why he didn’t ask me; he probably thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed now. "Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!" She lowered her book. She looked about thirty-five, older than me. A schoolteacher type. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." "Could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist (even though I didn’t have a watch). I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 

They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets. Then I heard the man talking. "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn’t know what to do." The woman listened sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet to see where he was going with this. "So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport." 

That seemed suspicious! Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? "Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. "I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought that was a weak excuse. It also seemed like too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one, the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, shares his thoughts about his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef. He believes that everyone has a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, while John had the opportunity to run a restaurant. When John learned about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it, even though it was in poor condition. He thought it was perfect for his plans.

Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembered feeling sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. This made him value family time. His wife took care of their children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made it a point to have meals together, which helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, giving them a good start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and accidentally knocked himself out. As he grew older, he earned pocket money by doing small jobs. By the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he always had money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before John. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John enjoyed seeing Gary contribute.

Although Gary was not very academic, he excelled in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John realized that Gary would pursue a career in catering. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John worries about what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one goal at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told Gary that he needed to achieve his goals by the age of 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary attended catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats, finishing his tasks in less than an hour. He even helped his classmates. John is amazed by Gary's success with his TV cooking show and feels very proud of him. He has always encouraged Gary to work hard for what he wants because nothing is given for free. Gary has recognized the opportunities he has and has taken full advantage of them. John believes that even if children only remember a small part of what their parents say, it is still a positive outcome. He sees that Gary listens and learns from him.

**Text: Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way to find one is through personal connections. If you know someone who knows someone else who is moving out, that can help. But if, like Jo, you have just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have those connections. You might have to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For Jo, Dublin felt like a big unknown place. She felt nervous when she took the train to start her job there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave her small town. They all wanted to escape and experience life. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm, as they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. However, Jo was unaware that they were still talking about her while she responded to an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen and bathroom." It was very close to her workplace and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.

There wasn’t a long line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and as Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. "Desperate place," she told Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt."

"Oh," Jo replied and continued up. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can’t stand her kind." 

"What did she do?" Jo asked.

"She didn’t do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and giggled, saying, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 

Pauline, wearing a very colorful shirt, looked like a punk, which surprised Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but had never talked to one before. 

"I'm Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa mentioned they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs—one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one labeled "Other." "We’ll put your name on a mug if you decide to stay," she offered kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of these animals.

Dolphins are special to us. They are among the most intelligent animals, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with dreams of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for dolphins has been supported by television shows. First, there was Flipper, and now we have Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the harsh reality of dolphins living in polluted and overfished waters.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such beloved animals would be protected by law and cared for in marine reserves, but this is not the case. The lack of plans to protect them could lead to one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are forty different types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups, so we know little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once frequently seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers like the Thames.
