Now, they can only be found in small numbers in places like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The injuries on the few remaining dolphins show that they are under stress.

The complex behavior of dolphins makes it hard to understand why their numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing industries, which also endangers porpoises and dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They are also at risk of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, hundreds of dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall, with injuries showing that they were caught in these nets.

Pollution in the sea can accumulate in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in their fat, and female dolphins produce milk that contains these toxins, which can harm their young. There is already a recorded case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activity. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**Getting Fit**

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you maintain balance in a world that often feels chaotic. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to. 

Exercise improves muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It increases muscle strength and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It also prevents muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries and improves specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. Additionally, exercise benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits before, but here’s something that might catch your attention: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can improve your sleep. It also helps manage stress and can relieve certain medical conditions. 

If you’re still not convinced, just remember that common sense tells us exercise is good for us. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to overdo it, as training too hard can lead to injuries. If you’re unsure about what exercises are right for you, it’s a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. Poor posture can make you look unattractive and can lead to low energy and health issues. If you tend to slouch, try to imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head upward. This can help you lift your chest for better breathing and make your body look slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It improves flexibility and helps you move easily, while also preventing injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. Your exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their comfortable homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. Among all the animals in the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest to find are Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost continuous rain, leading to several unexpected challenges. Newman mentioned that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their collaboration has produced some of television's best wildlife films, including a well-received documentary about leopards. While this film about one of Africa's most elusive cats was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time tracking the equally shy jackal.

This is common in television partnerships. Traveling filmmakers have been exploring the world to capture exotic wildlife on camera since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. "We do have occasional arguments, but we usually resolve them quickly," he said about his colleague. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and he believes they get along well because they both view the animals similarly. "When we are on the move, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we are working from a more fixed camp, so we prepare tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packaged food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so meal preparation can be stressful," Newman explained. 

It can be a tough life, but the advantage of being in such remote areas is that they can get close to the animals and become part of their lives. Newman recalled a time when they were filming a family of lions. One lioness would often wander off alone, but when she returned, she would greet all the other lions in her pride, and eventually, she included their vehicle in her greetings.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift," and two years later, they began filming Arctic foxes together. Since then, they have learned to spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. "Amanda and I developed a strong working relationship from the beginning," Newman said, "because it was clear we shared the same ideas and vision. Our goal is to create a film that captures the atmosphere, brings to life the true spirit of the place and its animals, and touches people's hearts. I believe that evoking an emotional response is much more powerful than just appealing to logic."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had just finished a typical day of teaching at a local school, followed by a training session in a supermarket car park. I was surprised by her choice of training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice much else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's it."

Kendra explained, "My life is all about being at my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to achieve maximum fitness. This will be her fourth World Championships, and it is expected to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong performance."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra mentioned, "We have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against because they have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra noted that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself every day; there is no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at a high level, the sport has become more intense and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don't train hard just to lose." But once the game is over, players become friends. 

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra stated, "It's essential for us to think and train like world-class players." As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra shared, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned." She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she is likely to have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, Rachel says, "Space is very limited. I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move around, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface."

"If there is a problem and we need to get to the top quickly, we can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel recalls her first dive: "I didn't know how I would react. I climbed into the vehicle on a ship with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing my reaction to being in such a small space." Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with their chimneys releasing black smoke. This is where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it to support my research on 'black smokers,' another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke, pouring out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

"The only time I felt scared was during my first dive with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang as shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible—we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I finally saw them in person, it was an amazing feeling."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Research shows that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone of voice, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believes being on time is very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who teaches at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, explains that interviewees who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. While many believe that what is inside matters most, it is essential to present yourself well in an interview.

Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also crucial not to seem too desperate for the job or overly eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and was offered the job immediately after her interview. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. Once her boss sensed her enthusiasm, he offered her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can greatly affect the success of an interview. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, reading the annual report can provide information about the company's activities. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview can create a positive impression and show your interest in the company. Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions prepared and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She states, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and highlight key points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City became boring—no one was enjoying it anymore. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I was unexpectedly made redundant. I didn’t receive a great severance package, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. Choosing to take redundancy and become an artist felt like the right decision. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a big change for us. We moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, our friendships have lasted, and many of them visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were long. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner, working even more hours, so I decided to leave. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. Since my business is fashion-related, I have collections and seasonal designs to manage, so there’s always a lot to do, and I need to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed. However, I do miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a poor job, I am the one to blame. Of course, you care when working for a company, but when your name is on the promotional materials, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I had been in financial markets since I was 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I chose to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That is the best part."

**Text: Dedicated to Their Sports**

Four young athletes share their experiences.

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always been active in sports. I tried many, but I excelled in football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it did not attract much media attention, which was disappointing. I had hoped for sponsorship, as training can be expensive. I train at home during the winter and then spend three weeks in Florida before the season starts. It’s enjoyable because the facilities are excellent and the nightlife is fun. However, I must be disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to decline. I wish I could go, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to qualify for the next Olympics—that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take their sport seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn, so I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I do miss sleeping in. However, it’s worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice getaway. The sacrifices pay off in the long run, as winning the championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I suppose I’m a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
Being on a boat with five guys is always fun. We have a traditional way of celebrating our wins. Some say we act a bit childish when we celebrate, but we don’t seek media attention. Often, reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to return home and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can’t focus on the sport all the time; it’s not healthy. I’m recognized in the sailing world, but I prefer to keep a low profile. I’ve only been recognized a few times in public, and I wouldn’t want to be a celebrity. I do receive many letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I make sure to reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It’s always exciting to walk onto the court and feel the support of the crowd. At my last tournament, things got a bit hectic with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping, but it has its challenges. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I received too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that contributed to our breakup. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in any sport; you must be serious and professional. I’m focused on my game now and plan to catch up on other aspects of life after I retire, which comes relatively early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get anxious before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that I’m not letting them learn how to make their own choices. It feels impossible."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. For children, the reasons their parents give for not buying certain things are often unclear. Arguments about how bad sugar is for their teeth are not convincing when compared to the appealing advertisements they see.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It’s important for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, as Dibb points out, "The main goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she still feels uneasy about how she handles their requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because we say they are bad for him, but we load our trolley with cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract enough extra customers to make up for it.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created by transforming four large 18th-century houses, a project that took nearly two years and involved extensive research into what customers want. This approach has allowed the hotel to install advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to track guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide a special experience for returning clients. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time due to its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers are a significant part of the hotel's clientele, making up about 65% of its business. To cater to their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. The hotel has also prepared for future technological advancements by installing extra cables and renting televisions, which can be easily replaced with newer models.

Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel features 145 spacious and well-furnished bedrooms that are inviting and cozy. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The food at the Merrion is of high quality, with Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who previously earned two Michelin stars, moving his restaurant to the hotel. This partnership benefits both the chef and the hotel, as he has designed a modern kitchen and improved parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant adds value without financial risk. With its combination of technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**Text: Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need to be challenged and learn new things. Right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing, which is very energizing. If I'm bored, I feel drained. Being effective, even in small ways, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. Work is not a chore for me. When I get enough sleep, I feel great. I know exercise boosts my energy, but sometimes it's hard to find the motivation. I do yoga once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to have a snack then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don't rely on healthy eating for energy; I think it's about being enthusiastic and positive. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. Being around lively young people energizes me. I enjoy taking photos and writing lyrics for fun, which helps me relax while traveling."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I love. I believe in my work and being positive. Working with kids gives me energy because they are so resilient. Energy is like a natural chemical that comes from connecting with others. Smiling at people can create a wonderful feeling. I try to eat healthily and avoid smoking and drinking, but I don't have a strict exercise routine. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is creating a garden from a wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a beautiful garden, which was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also gives me energy. I enjoy sneaking into nature, and if caught, I playfully say I didn't know it was private."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe it's important to have an interest in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don't want to do drains my energy. I used to be part of many committees, but I found them demanding. You have limited energy, so focus on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the upper classes in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but everything changed at the 1924 Winter Olympics when 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating very popular. Today, skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. The way you position your body is key to maintaining balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed, leaning a bit forward. Relaxation is essential in skating, more than in many other sports. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outward. As you push off with your back foot, make a small movement with your other foot. It’s not too hard! If you keep practicing, you can gradually make longer movements as you improve.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, stay relaxed to reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel first, then stand up. Once you feel confident moving on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle.

With proper instruction available at most ice rinks, you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you’ll be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle. If you watch skilled skaters, you’ll notice how relaxed and fluid their movements are. To achieve this, it’s important to follow a regular exercise routine. Skating with a stiff body can be risky, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, and especially your ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also boosts heart and lung health and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates an excellent program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Bills**

If there is one thing that can make you cry with joy, it is seeing a talented child receive a medal. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges of their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She hopes to become a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take it one day at a time, and when I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off. But usually, I just keep going because taking too many days off makes me stiff."

B. **Annika's mother**: "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen some parents push their children, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level requires a lot of time and energy, and you have to want to do it yourself. People often say that we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence through her success."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at the age of ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents enjoy show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun of show-jumping. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I am determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I’m not doing it for them. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's mother**: "From the moment Sarah first sat on a horse at age one, I knew she had found her passion. When she was five, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living quarters of our horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is completely happy on a horse and knows what she is doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is an incredible feeling."

E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about becoming arrogant; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like feeling embarrassed."

F. **Jane's mother**: "Jane played her first game when she was five. My father suggested we see if she liked it. He had tried to teach me when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age six, she was beating adults. Of course, I’m proud when she wins, but if she decided to stop playing tomorrow, I wouldn’t stop her. I also don’t want to discourage her because she is exceptional. If she has this talent, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimetre. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, "We are starting to reach our true potential," similar to the Cro-Magnons who lived 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be beneficial, some anthropologists see it as a health disaster. Still, agriculture spread because one piece of land could support many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are poorly nourished, but this issue is only recently being addressed, even in wealthier countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Although people are getting taller, some things have not changed. The standard bed length has been 190 cm since 1860, and legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased. Clothing manufacturers are constantly adjusting their products to fit taller people. 

The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. There must be a limit. According to Robert Fogel from the University, this limit could be around 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be getting taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. 

During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller, which helped them stay warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If global warming continues, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this topic. Like technical problems, studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people find them mysterious. When we see audiences getting excited on game shows, we often wonder: who are these people?

Studio audiences are often seen as the least important type of audience. Some people in the television industry even look down on them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience; they come from various backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract different types of people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home cannot understand why someone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would anyone apply for tickets, travel far, and endure hours of boredom just to watch something they could see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on television. I didn’t believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said, “I came for a chance to be on TV.” Another reason is that people are curious about what happens behind the scenes. However, the most common reason I heard was, “A friend gave me a ticket.”

Few of us have been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you respond accordingly. This may be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, “We believe a good show shouldn’t need these signs.”

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is “more exciting,” while Charlotte enjoyed the feeling of being part of a live show. “Last year, I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him on TV, you miss a lot.” What I missed was seeing the live actors; from my seat, I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were filmed far from where I sat, so I ended up watching the show on a monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that’s not what matters. For most audience members, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Simplified Text:**

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I do not like completely wild landscapes. I find the human touch important. This is also true when I travel abroad. I am attracted to charming villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England, and on Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I enjoyed exploring the bare hilltops, sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. In a way, that was my first attempt at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway that runs from Hythe to Dungeness, operated by volunteers. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive than the regular ticket. The scenery is not amazing. The train travels across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. However, there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when our small train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers see people in their homes, making tea, washing dishes, or setting up a deckchair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into other people's lives. It is the simplicity of the landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. This makes me look more closely and search for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and filled with rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to enjoy the beauty of the sea. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into lovely damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there and not many visitors either. It is a quiet and remote area, and I enjoy the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and since then, I have visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit.
