**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. It was about finding peace and reconnecting with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is the house of my dreams. It is a magical, secluded, and romantic place. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**Text: HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals of all kinds. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a beautiful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked excitedly. I agreed, but only for one night. We prepared a special tank for the snake, just for a short visit, so we could admire it and look it up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly started boiling some water when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their room. The chaos involved our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca, which I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape while avoiding the children who were waving their arms.

In the confusion, I tripped and fell. As I thought about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake had escaped. It was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the cat, mouse, and kids were all jumping around in a noisy mess. The snake was striking, and our dog was barking loudly. Meanwhile, the pot in the kitchen boiled over, so I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos.

With renewed energy, I grabbed Domino by the tail and rescued the small, wet, and surprisingly unharmed mouse from his jaws. Interestingly, this same mouse was caught by Domino three more times in its life but eventually died of old age.

Feeling encouraged by my success, I looked at the snake to find a way to catch it. It seemed impossible. In the end, I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth, but without any music. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, though its eyes still looked wary. I carefully slid my hands under the snake and stood up, then walked to the end of the garden. There, I pointed the snake towards a tree, giving it the chance to live freely.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to attack me, it instead wrapped itself around my shoulders like a colorful scarf, seeming to settle in for the winter. We stood together in the fading light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My oldest child, DJ, broke the silence with a comment: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't."

I asked the children to gather at the snake's tail and gently encourage it to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished from our sight, my three-year-old, Clay, sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Simplified Text:**

"Drop me a line! In our fast-paced world of phones, faxes, and computers, the traditional art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter brings a special joy that no other form of communication can match. There is excitement when a letter arrives, pleasure in seeing who it is from, and enjoyment in reading its contents.

Letter writing has been a part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote, and I loved receiving his long, funny letters. Most of the letters from home shared everyday news about my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I often dated people who had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch through letters. Instead of hurting our relationships, writing letters seemed to strengthen them. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than in conversation.

I enjoy the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but it’s even better to receive a whole year’s worth of news! I especially love getting airmail envelopes with beautiful stamps. I have friends who write to me from different countries, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. There’s also a lady from France who writes to me. If we hadn’t met in a restaurant on the way home from a holiday, I would never have had her address. Thankfully, she replied to my letters, and now we have a regular correspondence. I can practice my French with her since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited her twice, and she has stayed with us.

My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our correspondence lasted so long. The local newspaper even featured our story on the front page.

I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have their own penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art."

**Simplified Text:**

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists worry that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not survive for future generations. The mountain, which was once a place for prayer and worship, has drawings that are about 4,000 years old. These include images of cows with horns, cultivated fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and blurs the artwork. Some visitors even break off pieces to take home as souvenirs. "When people think they can't take a good enough photograph, they rub the drawings to get a clearer picture," he explains. "The drawings are polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers report that some people arrive with long sticks that have sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He warns that if this is not done, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.

Clottes disagrees, saying, "Henry de Lumley's plan is the most extreme, and while it may be effective, it will certainly cause protests from local residents." He adds, "The site was declared a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect what is there."

David Lavergne, the regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal. Our department believes the best solution is to let people visit the site, but because the area is very large, it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage. I would prefer that everyone could see it, but the main issue is money. We do not have enough funds to hire the necessary number of guards. We may need to consider charging a fee, as there seems to be no chance of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also researched the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to access—tourists can now avoid the three-and-a-half-hour walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to close off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she says. "That is not acceptable. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for future generations."

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder." She explains that her children want everything they see, whether it’s the newest sugary cereal, a Disney video, or a comic book—often all three. She feels guilty when she buys them these things, but she also hates saying no all the time. This makes her feel frustrated before they even leave home. Although she tries to avoid taking them shopping, she worries that she is not letting them learn how to make their own choices. 

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot afford certain items, and arguments about the health risks of sugar are not convincing when compared to the appealing advertisements they see.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance states that most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, although these ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food, as children who only hear about products from advertisements get a very limited view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb notes that the main goal of advertising is still to persuade viewers to make purchases, even if they do not directly say, "Tell your mom to buy this."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother mentions that she tries to be patient when discussing food with her children, but she feels uneasy about how she handles their requests. She says her son pays attention to advertisements but is critical of them. They often talk about different products and read labels together. Because of this, her children rarely ask for things she does not want to buy.

Parents also admit they can be inconsistent in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, explains that they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they believe they are unhealthy, while they themselves buy rich foods like double cream and chocolate. He finds it enjoyable to buy nice things and understands why children want to share in that. However, he still feels annoyed by their requests. His willingness to say yes often depends on his mood and how well things are going in his life.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. While parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without constant demands from their kids could attract more customers, making up for any loss in sales.

**Text: Going Up the Wall**

In the past, climbers went to the mountains to climb. Now, people can enjoy climbing in many places, both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches closely as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is better known for hosting the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common: The Wall. The ability to hold such events is due to new and rapidly advancing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on natural cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they either dealt with the cold, went for walks, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they began to train on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them strengthen their fingers and avoid boredom from not climbing.

Soon, many sports centers started building climbing walls specifically for training, using bricks with special edges. One of the first climbing walls was created by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He came up with the idea of embedding natural rock in concrete blocks to create climbing walls. Throughout the 1970s, many similar walls were built in sports halls across the country, but they had clear design issues. These walls could only be vertical, while outdoor cliffs have features like overhangs and slanted rocks. Additionally, once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny invented a material that could be shaped like the holds found on cliffs. These holds could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a change. French manufacturers also started to create panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for making overhanging walls without significant construction, but steel frames could be built anywhere as free-standing structures. This system of interchangeable holds provided climbers with endless new challenges.

**Text: 'So You Want to Be an Actor'**

If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will likely mention that it is a risky career. Acting is indeed risky because there are many actors but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to pursue acting, some people you thought were friends may think you are making a mistake, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice, but ultimately, it is a personal choice, and you are responsible for your own path and dreams.

There are no easy ways to succeed in acting. There are no exams to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee of success. Success often depends on a mix of luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and the profession can offer excitement, glamour, and sometimes financial rewards.

Many people ask what talent is. I believe talent is a combination of natural skill and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to measure. Talent also involves courage and confidence in what you are doing. 

The desire to act can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often do not have a clear answer. They understand their own skills and those of others, but they do not take their success for granted. They know they are only as good as their last job, and fame can be fleeting.

Disappointment is a major challenge for actors. One month, you might be unemployed, working in a store or as a waitress. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. However, even if you want the job badly, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid discussing their chances of success. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection, which is something no one enjoys. 

From the moment you start auditioning, you are saying you are available and hopefully talented enough for the role. Ultimately, it is up to you; if you do not care enough about your career, others may not care about you either.

**Food for All**

We are excited to share our carefully chosen selection of the best cookbooks available. 

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and author, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many different cultures, reflecting her passion for delicious food and her understanding of what the average person can cook in a regular kitchen. The book that made her famous is *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, which has become a key reference for modern cooks. It offers clear guidance on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of exciting recipes. Recently updated, it answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc took just 15 years to go from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain. To support his first TV series, *Blanc Mange*, he has released a book with the same title. Raymond aims to help everyone become better cooks by explaining how and why certain ingredients behave in specific ways. He believes that good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book includes over 80 fantastic recipes that illustrate his points. It is a practical guide that also explains why some dishes may fail and introduces basic food science to clarify these ideas. Monsieur Blanc enjoys cooking for others, and this book shows that he is very skilled at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in classical French cooking. For the past 100 years, the expert chefs at this renowned cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve excellence. To celebrate its centenary, they have published the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, featuring 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While these recipes are traditional, they are also fresh and modern. Le Cordon Bleu has always promoted classic French cooking but has adapted its recipes to reduce rich sauces and calories. The book starts with basic kitchen techniques and includes sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is accompanied by step-by-step illustrations and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have contributed their famous recipes and shared their tips.

D. Fast food? No way! It is often thought that good food requires a long time to prepare. However, Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, disagrees. His new book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes that people want good food quickly when they come home tired and hungry. He has always thought it is possible to make something tasty in the same time it takes to order a pizza, and he has already published two successful books to prove it. In this new book, you will find many appealing recipes, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel shares over 200 recipes from around the world in his cheerful and engaging style. Just because he enjoys quick meals doesn’t mean he doesn’t value good food. If you doubt that fast food can be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimetre. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, "We are starting to reach our true potential," similar to the Cro-Magnons who lived 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many natural areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a blessing, some anthropologists see it as a public health problem. Still, agriculture spread because one piece of land could support many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people are poorly nourished, but this issue is only recently being addressed, even in wealthier countries. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive trend, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have decreased, and clothing manufacturers are constantly adjusting their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? Experts suggest there might be a limit, possibly around 193 cm, which we could reach this century. 

However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If global warming continues, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in the business, I found that working in the City became boring—no one was enjoying it anymore. I had planned to stay for another five or ten years, but then I was unexpectedly made redundant. I didn’t receive a great severance package, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the best restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat through mail order. I’m happy to be out of the office, but it’s surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. Choosing to take redundancy and become an artist felt like the right choice. The career counselor I spoke to was very supportive. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to find work quickly for financial reasons. My wife and I married young, and our children no longer need our support. It was a big change for us. We moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, our friendships have lasted, and many of them visit us now."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was enjoyable and well-paid, but the hours were long. I realized I didn’t want to become a senior partner, working even more hours, so I decided to leave. Many people said I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to set deadlines. Since my business is fashion-related, I have collections and seasonal designs to manage, so there’s always a lot to do, and I need to keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and much less stressed. However, I do miss the social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a poor job, I am the one who faces the consequences. Of course, you care when working for a company, but when your name is on the promotional materials, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I had been in financial markets since I was 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I never found the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I chose to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the best gyms in the world and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then, I was offered part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That is the best part."

**Text: A Winning Game**

Two brothers have discovered that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are at their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, enjoying their childhood memories. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing pichenotte, an ancient game that they believe is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and introduced it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played the game and, as Dave says, "had the best time ever." Eventually, they moved to New Mexico, but they continued to play with Grandpa's pichenotte board, which he had made from old wooden crates. Visitors were often intrigued because the game was unknown in the southern USA.

Three years ago, Dave noticed how worn the pichenotte board had become and decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative wanted one, and then a friend asked for another. Curious about the interest, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," says Dave, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon, they couldn't get up from the table!" When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched it. He found that the roots likely come from India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. This game evolved into 'squails,' played in British pubs, and British immigrants brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec.

Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' that are flicked across a wheel-like board using one hand. Scoring a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points, while three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points, respectively. There are also eight small posts that act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity increased. Championships began, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, and the brothers decided to start a pichenotte business full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and have produced over 450 boards. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12 kg and is 1 cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable, as they have to withstand a lot of use." They are available for $595 each on the brothers' website.

Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage to create pichenotte stars. However, the day may come when the brothers' garage will be home to a luxury Mercedes instead of tools and wood. Until then, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was an overgrown piece of waste land. For a long time, it was seen as useless. However, through careful planning and hard work by one man, with the support of his wife, this land has been transformed into the beautiful site you see today. 

During the construction of the village, many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into a sculpted landscape. Although machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of manual labor was also involved. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rockeries. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted, carefully chosen to survive in the salty air near the sea and to withstand strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were imported from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The entire village was designed by Colin Sims, who created over 100 models over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from various materials—stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics—to endure different weather conditions. Initially, Colin needed help from experts to understand how materials would hold up over time, but he quickly became skilled himself. 

You will notice that a consistent scale has been maintained, and great attention has been given to even the smallest details of the models. This was achieved through patience and the development of unique building techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality craftsmanship and upkeep. The methods used to create these realistic models have been adopted in other model villages across England and are even taught in some college courses on modeling.

All the buildings in the village represent traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific place. One of the most impressive structures is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses found in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition to the village.

We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models, as any damage can lead to hours of repair work for us. You may take photographs from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.

To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Pressing these will make the models operate. At the end of your visit, we welcome your feedback. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet your expectations, as we are continually updating and replacing them.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Please tell your friends about us!

Text: 

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and violate the editors' code of practice. While some pop stars do pose for paparazzi sometimes, this is not the norm. More often, serious harm is done to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people report these issues to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle such problems. Rarely are these pictures in the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has previously complained about long-lens photos, and since she was in a hotel—a place where people expect privacy—she had a valid reason to complain, but she did not take action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. It should also look into the recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take the lead on this and other disgraceful incidents? 

At first glance, this seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and on TV and radio. The public would not support such actions, and editors would have to stop publishing this kind of material. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to afford to hide behind trees to take pictures of unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several challenges. How would it decide whether to start an investigation? Should it contact the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still refused to act, should the PCC proceed anyway? Additionally, celebrities and royals might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and they could be upset if it wasn’t. 

Moreover, the role of the PCC is too vast. How could it realistically monitor all of the British press: national, regional, and magazines? There is also the issue of embarrassment to consider. Even if someone's privacy has been violated, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most likely, they just want to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. They might be hiding a worse story from the press and fear that it could come out if they complain. In other words, even the PCC could become a problem for them. 

One British comedian faced issues with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, nor did he when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. His reason was the fear that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', claiming they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would have a sense of humor about it. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is difficult to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Text: "Many college graduates receive advice about starting their first job. This article focuses on moving to a second job. We are not discussing those who are looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, nor those who leave a job they dislike within a few weeks. Instead, we will talk about those of you who are ready to take a significant step in your career. You have gained some experience and skills and have a clearer idea of your career goals. 

What kind of job should you seek? It largely depends on your long-term goals. You need to consider whether you want to specialize in a certain area, aim for higher responsibilities, or explore a broader field. Whatever you choose, it is important to select your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years, as it will be closely examined by future employers when you apply for your next position. This job should demonstrate that you have thought seriously about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and provide you with more responsibilities.

If you have a desire to travel, now might be a good time to do so. You can take temporary work when you return and then find your second job later. Future employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your travel interests and are less likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three solicitors. It was a great first job because they were very supportive. She learned how to navigate an office and improved her word processing skills. However, there was no opportunity for advancement. Eventually, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, 'In two and a half years, I have become more capable, and my job has really evolved. From the start, my boss was eager to help me grow. My job title is the same as when I began, but my responsibilities have changed. I now handle most of the correspondence and budgets, and I deal with various inquiries, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes me in all her work and also assigns me specific projects and events to organize.'"

**Text: 'What is the Secret of Confident People?'**

Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but many will say it is a skill they learned over time. Nina Hathway interviews five individuals about how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At about twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter’s school. I was nervous but surprised myself by doing well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I felt very anxious, but my confidence grew over time, and I became more outgoing. Looking back, working at the school was a turning point in my life.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey began four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became overly aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that true confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work becomes too much, I don’t feel guilty about postponing tasks. When facing challenges, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can destroy confidence, so I often talk to myself to overcome those fears.

**C. Lisa**  
People see me as confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to appear confident because it is essential in TV. Interviewing people has shown me that many of us feel tense in important situations, but we feel better when talking to friendly people. My mother once told me that everyone is too busy worrying about their own appearance to notice me. I remember this advice often. I also believe that facing your fears helps build confidence. I was nervous during my driving test, but after passing, I felt I could handle anything.

**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am well-liked in the restaurant, but not everyone will like you. It’s important to accept yourself and not try to meet others' expectations. My company offers training courses that have boosted my self-esteem. Setting achievable goals helps you see your progress instead of aiming too high and feeling disappointed.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up, even when I disagreed. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with nerves. I told myself, “Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.” I also found it helpful to write down points to refer to, like a comfort blanket. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking publicly. The real secret to confidence is reminding yourself that “Nothing is impossible.”

**Text: Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You should keep it," he said, "it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finders keep it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat in the shade of the whispering conifer trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking out at Malaysia's largest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, ten platforms held up the kites, while tense competitors waited with their kite lines for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites shot into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days each year. Each participant entered four different designs, judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying efficiency. 

"Flying kites isn't too hard," Adnan said, "but making them requires real skill. Come visit me at home, and I'll show you how." This was one of five invitations I received that day, and I decided to accept. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, polished room. As night fell, he invited me to return the next day to start rebuilding his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through granite mountains covered in lush rainforest. 

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take pedestrians across. Nearby, a sign caught my attention. It pointed up a footpath into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started, it would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was steep and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. 

The night was completely dark, filled with various sounds. A nearby waterfall roared, and thousands of creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, I enjoyed a stunning view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First came the wind, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. As I slid downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the heavy raindrops. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the risk of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. 

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their curiosity was friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I will always remember it for the kindness of its people.

**Text: What Type of Shopper Are You?**

Shopping is something we all do, whether we enjoy it or not. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know what type you are? Abby Edwards asked several people about their shopping habits:

A. **Melanie, 22, Dancer**  
"I love shopping! When I have money, I go out and feel happy. I can't resist sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're both addicted!"

B. **Brenda, 40, Office Manager**  
"I'm not a fan of shopping. My husband does most of the grocery shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I take my kids shopping for clothes, but it’s not fun since we all have different styles. I rarely buy things for myself, and when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less than I actually did."

C. **Juliet, 28, Personnel Manager**  
"I only shop for what I need. I dislike shopping and only go when necessary. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and won’t settle for anything else. Shopping feels exhausting to me."

D. **Anita, 35, TV Producer**  
"I enjoy browsing sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and prefer to shop quickly. However, I do have some items in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I’m careful but sometimes make mistakes."

E. **Lizzie, 41, Secretary**  
"I really dislike shopping, especially for clothes. I can never find what I want or get help. The stores are too noisy and messy, which makes it a nightmare for me. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often since I receive many as gifts. For groceries, I go to the supermarket once a week and get it done quickly."

F. **Lisa, 22, Actress**  
"I would say I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my friends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually have a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I’ll buy it."

G. **Suki, 26, Art Gallery Assistant**  
"I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t go overboard. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often regret spending too much."

H. **Ann-Marie, 29, Nursery Worker**  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too crowded. I’m a careful shopper; I have a good idea of what I want and don’t rush into buying things. I like to check other stores to find better deals, which takes me a long time."

I. **Linda, 32, Restaurant Manager**  
"I don’t like shopping, maybe because I work in the city center and the shops don’t excite me anymore. When I have to shop, I go without trying things on because it’s too much effort. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind making mistakes rather than spending too much time in stores."

**Text: NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE**

The Open University offers degrees just like any other university. The difference is that you can study while continuing to work. This experience can introduce you to many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will find joy in gaining knowledge. You will also meet a diverse group of people. Additionally, your degree may lead to new job opportunities.

At the Open University, you do not attend traditional lectures. Instead, you study from home using resources like television, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can attend one class each month at an Open University center. Like any university, there are exams to complete.

If you want to learn more, simply fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can participate in a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets are available at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and asked various questions about them. The quiz sheets can be collected from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Artwork**  
The Gallery now features a beautiful still life by the Dutch painter Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) depicts flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for artists to date their work in two years, as they wait for specific flowers to bloom in different seasons. This artwork was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is currently displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition titled "Painting in Spain during the Late 18th Century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this time: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

**Lecture Series**  
The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss Melendez's work, while Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret on 12 April. Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu on 19 and 26 April. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often tell stories through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is pleased to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide variety of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Visitor Information**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours highlight some of the Gallery's greatest artworks and showcase its collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Text: Little Chefs**

For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are dedicated to learning serious cooking. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children wanting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I was happy at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to cook for themselves when they leave home."

**Text:**

The Outdoor Centre Fees are for a car with four people. Each additional person costs 50p. Fees should be paid at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organization that aims to provide outdoor sports and recreation facilities for everyone. Group visitors are asked to inform the centre in advance about their planned visit.

**Windsurfing - One-day Course**  
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays when the weather is suitable. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Boards with small sails are provided for beginners. Course fee: £32.50 (this includes all equipment).

**One-day Adventure Course**  
This is a chance you have been waiting for. Come and try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is designed to introduce outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have previous experience. All you need is an interest in the activities. Course fee: £22.50.

**Play Park**  
The Play Park is suitable for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best parks of its kind in the country. It features sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

**Group Day and Residential Courses**  
We also offer day and weekend courses for groups. We regularly host visits from schools, colleges, and youth groups. There are three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

**Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)**  
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are fully trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities offered. We ensure that all children participate in activities that are suitable for their age and physical abilities. For this program, children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting, a hobby that is both interesting and enjoyable. Each year, more individuals start their own stamp collections and find a passion that can last a lifetime. 

Starting your collection is simple because stamps are easy to find. You can collect stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends. Once you begin collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club, which helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps for your collection in three ways: 

1. We can send you a complete set of stamps in an envelope.
2. We can provide the same stamps in a colorful information pack filled with interesting facts.
3. If you prefer, we can send you individual stamps for you to organize in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has around 70,000 members, and you can join for just £5 for two years. If a group of you joins together, you can even get a discount. This is a great deal! When you join, you will receive a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack includes 100 stamps to kickstart your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You will also get a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to grow your collection and a list of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will receive the club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes, and gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members worldwide. 

Why not start an adventure that will bring you years of enjoyment? You will spend many happy hours looking at the wonderful variety of stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones that are waiting to be discovered. 

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and experience the fun of stamp collecting! To become a member, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of receiving your application.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are similar to a gram or a kilometre. The key difference is that you can trade money for goods or services. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money as we understand it today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a direct exchange between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of 'currency' to facilitate more exchanges. Eventually, different currencies began to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.

**Text: Write a Winning Story!**

You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky winners will receive a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges include Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a television reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story.

You can write about anything you like, but here are some tips to help you:

1. **Write About What You Know**: This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most stories were about love, family, and friendship problems. Try to make ordinary situations interesting so that people want to read them.

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: Make sure your descriptions and information are accurate. If you are unsure about something, do not include it in your story.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start with an interesting beginning and end with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a good story. Develop your story carefully and think of something unusual for the ending.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using descriptive language. 

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and printed on one side of each page. We cannot accept stories sent by fax or email, even if you are close to the deadline. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, we cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. 

You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, as per a new rule. Your story must not have been published in any form, including on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. 

Your entry fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Please make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that she received the best education possible. This was rare, as most women at that time had limited opportunities for study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created several scientific tools to assist her work. During her time, many rulers feared science, and those involved in it were often in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is a twelve-kilometre-long railway that runs through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is near the A1 main road. There is also a two-kilometre extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to the peaceful area of Yarwell, the current western end of the line.  
**Fares:** Adult £10.00, Child £5.00, Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children) £25.00. Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site, making it a great place for a family day out. The park has thousands of hectares of public land with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station features a unique collection of historic trains from various parts of Europe. This includes the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can see these engines all year round, regardless of whether the Nene Valley Railway is operating. However, the buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can easily look like a railway from any part of Europe. A notable example is its appearance in the James Bond movie "Octopussy." Come and see where it was filmed!

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups to visit and for teachers to set projects. Students can work on projects while at the railway or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, school groups can hire the 'Teddy Bear' train with up to 3 carriages on non-service days, but they need to book at least one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. For more information, call 01780 784444.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a popular venue for special family events or company visits. It can provide a unique setting for an interesting afternoon or evening. Special programs can be arranged to include a buffet, bar, entertainment, and discos. For more details, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

**Text: Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they can be found in every part of the earth. Grass is unique because it can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way.

One interesting feature of grass is that it grows back quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike many other plants, new leaves of grass grow from below the ground, not from the top. This ability allows many animals to live together in the same area. When they eat all the grass in one spot, new grass starts to grow again, providing a fresh food source.

Text: Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion and recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since childhood, she has enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who run a supermarket, about her dream to make fashion her career. She believed they wanted her to pursue a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. Although she attended industry events, she could not afford the designer clothes she admired. To solve this, she began making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends noticed her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. She then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis. The clothes were very popular, and nothing was returned. This success motivated her to leave her advertising job, take out a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. Her parents were supportive of her decision, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she gained public recognition by winning this award. She feels fortunate about her journey, saying, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Sunningdale Hotel**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service to guests from around the world, welcoming people of all ages and nationalities. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed at Sunningdale. The hotel is located on a main road that leads to the town center, which is about a 20-minute bus ride away. Buses to various parts of the town stop right outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with a blue "Express" sign, as they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are located at the end of the corridors. The hotel offers a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos available for guests to use. Parking spaces for cars are available in the hotel driveway. Daily newspapers are provided for free, and stamps can be purchased at the office.

Guests staying for long periods must pay for their accommodation weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are as follows: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. For those studying or working late during the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by signing the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices available for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires of any kind (for cooking or heating) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect the comfort of others. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise level low, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests arriving by train are advised to take a taxi to the hotel, as it is some distance from the main railway station.

**Text: Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in film history. However, his life has not always been easy. As a child, Tom was shy and struggled to make friends, even though he loved participating in school plays. After finishing high school, he moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter while also taking drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he had become so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions for each film. Today, Tom continues to act in films and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after a long trip of over 500 kilometers. Both the driver and Bo were hungry at the end of the day. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. As it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, Bo's owner had also been searching for her. After looking everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he recalled the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

**Simplified Text:**

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across the Australian continent, from the warm northern coast through vast deserts to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds of up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is very good. The railway was originally built to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to southern Australia via Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent. It is rare to complete a transcontinental railway, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south railway.

As I waited to board the Ghan, I noticed that everyone was excited about the journey. Many of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners who were eager to get on the train. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and enjoyed the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week heading south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting; there is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was ending, and although the train did not meet all the promises made in advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Text: Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is located in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred metres high, making it one of the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowls cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. These spikes are necessary because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. Even though some members of our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to signal for help, hard hats, and extra clothing. 

Although the weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, there was still a sense of nervousness when we started our climb. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path quickly became steep, and my legs felt heavy. As the weakest member of the group, I needed to take more breaks. The others sometimes paused to let me catch up, but as soon as I arrived, they would start again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only a metre and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of metres on both sides. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on each step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometres away. Unfortunately, we were not so lucky, as a mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be just as challenging as going up. You need to be able to read a map well; a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns with this task. It was only when I was safely in the tent that I could say I truly enjoyed the experience. But at least I made it to the top.

**Text: Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the entire structure, similar to our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The school took many months to build, and we watched the process. It was thrilling to see the builders clear the land, even though it meant some beautiful open space was lost. The noise from the construction machines was quite loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. At times, we worried that the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five large classrooms, much bigger than those in our old school, which was very old. We also share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is a nursery, a lovely dining room, and spacious changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the warmth comes from everyone inside—the students, teachers, and computers. The building is designed to keep the heat and sound inside, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting feature is that the school roof has a tree on it! The builders placed it there after finishing the roof, as it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for our lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so large that it can be seen from far away! We took some pictures to share on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being completed. For example, we are currently preparing a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to perform it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever considered joining a book club and receiving new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**How to Join:**
To become a member, simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate Benefits:**
As a special offer, you can choose any reduced-price books from our new members' list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money compared to the publishers' prices. You can also tick a box on your form to receive a free watch. If you respond within seven days, we will send you another free gift selected from our book list by our staff. You can order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**As a Member:**
Once you join, you will enjoy discounts of 30% to 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered directly to your home. You will receive a free club magazine every month, which will keep you informed about the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Membership Requirements:**
While you are a member, we ask you to choose four books in your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want to order. In each monthly magazine, our experienced staff will select a "Club Choice" book—a fiction or reference title that they believe is especially worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just let us know on the form. If we do not hear from you, we will send the book anyway.

So, return your application form today, but hurry—this is a special offer! To apply for membership, simply fill in the enclosed form and return it in the prepaid envelope. Before you know it, your books will arrive. Please do not send any money now; we will send you a bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation was basic, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. 

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn were with Amanda. We all came from different places and none of us knew the area well. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we were not sure how. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock-climbing, and then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally made it out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had accomplished.'

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I accidentally left my handbag on the bus. Inside were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized my mistake, it was too late. I felt lost: I am 72 years old, far from home, and quite worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what had happened, and he kindly gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I explained the situation to the bus driver, he told me I could keep the fare. I made it home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had found it and offered to bring it back to me. I was amazed to get my handbag back, with everything inside still there. I want to express my gratitude to everyone who helped me that day and to acknowledge their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Text: Sharks**

Sharks are among the most intimidating animals in our oceans. They are well adapted for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they prey on. 

While sharks share some similarities with other fish, their bodies are quite different. For instance, most sharks must keep swimming constantly to breathe and survive, which means they hardly ever sleep. Additionally, if sharks are flipped onto their backs, they can stop moving entirely. This is a useful method for researchers who need to study sharks, as it helps them learn more about these intriguing animals.
