**Text: Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. In nearly every town, you can find clubs and classes for this enjoyable activity. 

"Line dancing is simple to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to meet new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began around fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino's great body rests on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they primarily eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos at birth and stays in its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino can weigh over 200 kilos and may live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, we see police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police force. A few elderly men tried to protect the streets at night, but they were not paid well. Around 300 years ago, London was growing larger. The city was very dirty, and many people lived in poverty. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, which made people stay at home as much as possible.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of individuals to catch thieves. They were similar to police officers and were known as the 'Bow Street Runners' because they operated near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had expanded significantly and required more police. Therefore, in 1829, the first Metropolitan Police Force was established with 3,000 officers. Most of these men patrolled on foot, while a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police officers are paid fairly well, and those who still ride horses earn even higher salaries than their colleagues.

Text: 'ATTENTION STUDENTS: Are you interested in a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers, a small shop, and bicycle rentals. The cost of the trip is £25. It gets very cold at night, so please bring warm clothes and wear sturdy shoes. If you want to join, please let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Experience the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is filled with actors and artists from around the world. They come to participate in the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are vibrant with music and dance from morning until night. You can even watch artists painting in the streets. A highlight of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists attend the Festival to see new films, plays, and listen to music from famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be challenging, so consider booking your hotel now!'

**ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they fish for the fish swimming beneath the ice. Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. 

"You need to wear clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top," he explains. "Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice to make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line, put some bread on it, and lower it through the hole into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people enjoy eating them, but after I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!"

Text: 

From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I’m having a tough week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us! Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can’t visit us during the holidays because he got a summer job. Now we can’t go camping together. This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I’m really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can.  

Greg

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's Museum

One well-known attraction for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. In this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous individuals. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie assisted him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to create wax models of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.'

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created around 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were quite expensive, and only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early models looked very different from modern bicycles. Over time, as bicycles became more affordable, many people began to buy them. People started using bicycles for commuting and leisure activities. 

Today, cars are more commonly used than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to cycle to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it difficult to find parking.

**Text: The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14**

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went directly to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and began to paint on its own card. Occasionally, the keepers would give a new brush filled with paint to each elephant and take the old one away. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they no longer work there, but the smartest of these animals live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats avoid water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These groups often work together to hunt for food. Lions typically inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and track other animals easily. All cats require good eyesight to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I regret to inform you that I can no longer attend your class because I must return to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I would like to go shopping with her to select a dress. My parents are planning to prepare a large meal for the guests, which will require a lot of work in the kitchen. I am truly sorry to leave the English class. You are an excellent teacher. Please convey my farewell to the other students.

Thank you once again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Text: 'Dear Lorna, 

How are you? I am excited to share that I got a new job in the city center last month. I am now working at a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to wake up quite early! I enjoy this job because I meet people from many different countries and I like to tell them about our city. Best, 
Gloria'

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, with adults weighing over 90 kilograms. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches can run very fast, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. They eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Text: Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has achieved success in many competitions. Recently, we interviewed her at a snowboarding event in Switzerland and asked why she chose this sport. She explained, "I have always enjoyed various sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It’s easy to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months."

When we inquired about her practice routine, she shared, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also enjoy running and biking. I truly love all of it! Competing and being in the mountains is wonderful. However, free-riding—doing what you want outside of competitions—is the best part for me."

We also asked her what is essential for beginners. She replied, "You can learn quickly, but taking lessons is important. Having the right clothing is crucial too, so you stay dry, especially since you will fall a lot at first!"

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have successfully climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are several routes to the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest and takes about five days to complete. It is very popular among tourists. However, only half of those who attempt to climb Kilimanjaro reach the summit. This is often due to sudden changes in weather. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, climbers encounter ice and snow, with temperatures possibly dropping below 20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, climbers should pack both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Text: Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were so polluted that many fish and insects died, leaving otters without food. However, today there is plenty of food for them because the rivers have become clean again.

Dear Deshini,

I am happy to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but I now live in England. Please write to me and share about your life in India. I would love to visit there someday. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? If you have any pictures of your school, could you send them to me? I am including a few photos of my family with this letter. I will send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon.

Best,  
Tom

17 Green Street

Dear John,

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a great teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then return home to Greece. I really like London. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. It was very sunny, and we had a wonderful time. Tonight, I will watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I will write again from Greece.

Best wishes,  
Kostas

Text: 

Dear David,

Next month, I will visit your country with two friends. We are unsure about where to stay. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We would prefer to stay in the city center. Can you assist us?

Carlos

Dear Carlos,

Hotels in the center can be costly, but I have some good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria, and she said you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! That will be fine for you, right?

David

**Text: Buildings**

People have always created buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful items. Many people work together on a building project. The architect decides how the building will look and creates drawings to share their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. 

The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with a stunning roof. However, the building is beautiful from all angles, not just from above. Another famous structure is the Olympic Stadium in Munich, which has a unique roof that resembles a glass tent.

Text: "Indre, I need your help with something. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The issue is that I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short for me now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you prefer to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Please let me know. Sarika"

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in southern England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man. This figure is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. The exact date when the Cerne Giant was created is unknown, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she plans to compete in the 10,000 metres and possibly the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always smiled and laughed, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of any British woman that year.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail, but it’s not enjoyable for him when she runs ahead and he cannot keep up. Gail trains hard; she does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she always takes Sundays off from running. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Text: Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six years old. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef has always loved music, but he is also interested in physics and languages. Although he is very busy now, he hopes to write his own music one day.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he became a children's book writer at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he shares his work with his wife, who tells him what she thinks. "She lets me know when she doesn't like something," says Bill. His ten grandchildren, who live far away, also read his stories and give their opinions.

Through this feedback, Bill has learned what young children enjoy reading. He writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, *The Sheepdog*, which tells the story of a farmer and his helpful dog. "I have always loved animals," Bill says, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." 

Last year, this book was turned into a film featuring real animals and actors. The filmmakers used advanced computer technology to make it seem like the animals were talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change the story, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many individuals send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often more appealing than personal photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it displayed a picture of a seaside town. Over time, postcards began to feature images related to current events, such as accidents or visits from important figures. People appreciated these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include pictures.

**Dinosaurs**

No one has ever seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaur died about 60 million years ago, long before people existed on Earth. We do not know exactly why they all became extinct. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were over 5,000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as large, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run quickly because it had long back legs.

**Bears**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can potentially harm a person. They are skilled climbers and can run quickly. However, their eyesight is poor, and like many animals, they rely on their sense of smell to find food. There are seven species of bears. The largest is the polar bear, which can grow to nearly three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one inhabits the forests of North America, while the other is found in Southeast Asia. Interestingly, not all black bears are actually black; some can be dark brown or reddish-brown. The black and white panda bear, native to China, is beloved by many. Unfortunately, there are not many pandas left in the wild today, as they struggle to find enough food.

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles are found in tropical regions around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually live in slow-moving water, but they can swim quickly and move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat a variety of things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Occasionally, they may also attack larger animals or even humans. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles, all of which have very sharp teeth. Although they often lose teeth, they quickly grow new ones. Typically, crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. They have long lifespans; the oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

**A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL**

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers invented the first powered airplane and successfully flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes underwent significant changes. By the 1950s, airplanes became much faster due to the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, capable of flying at 2,500 kilometers per hour, which allows the trip from London to New York to take only four hours. Today, millions of people fly on airplanes, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

Text: 'The Globe Theatre

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round and had no roof, so people could get cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, located by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, talk to their friends, walk around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same location near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I am enjoying my holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now, the weather has improved, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are in Sydney, but next week we will visit the Great Barrier Reef. The water is very warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, and purple! Australia is truly beautiful, and we don’t want to go home! I will see you at the end of September.

Sue
